dt: {bc}the watery, clear portion of an animal fluid:

{bc}the clear, yellowish fluid that remains from blood plasma after clotting factors (such as fibrinogen and prothrombin) have been removed by clot formation {bc}{sx|blood serum||} {dx}compare {dxt|antiserum||}, {dxt|convalescent serum||}{/dx}
{bc}a normal or pathological {d_link|serous fluid|serous fluid} (as in a blister)
{bc}a usually lightweight cosmetic preparation especially for use on the face
{bc}a typically water-based, often concentrated preparation that lacks lubricating and thickening agents
{bc}the watery part of a plant fluid

dt.t: Latex. This, the natural product of the rubber tree, is a suspension of rubber droplets in a watery {wi}serum{/wi} concentrated and stabilized in such a way that the dry rubber content is between 60 and 70 per cent.

et: borrowed from Latin, "whey, wheylike fluid," of uncertain origin

Latin {it}serum{/it} has been conventionally linked with Greek {it}orós,{/it} of identical meaning, and both compared with the Sanskrit verbal base {it}sar-,{/it} allegedly meaning " flow" in Vedic texts (hence P. Chantraine in {it}Dictionnaire étymologique de la langue grecque{/it}). More recently, however, this interpretation has been rejected, and {it}sar-{/it} read as "run off"—hence Vedic Sanskrit {it}ásarat{/it} "ran off," {it}prasísarti{/it} "lets run, stretches, extends," not akin to {it}sáraḥ{/it} "lake, pond" and related words, which describe still water. The Sanskrit etymon has been further compared with Greek {it}hállomai{/it} "(I) spring, hop," Latin {it}salīre{/it} "to jump" (see {et_link|sally:2|sally:2}). If this is correct the Indo-European base is {it}*sel-,{/it} and any connection to {it}serum{/it} and {it}orós{/it} impossible; these two words are left then without any certain etymology.
shortdef: the watery, clear portion of an animal fluid:
the clear, yellowish fluid that remains from blood plasma after clotting factors (such as fibrinogen and prothrombin) have been removed by clot formation : blood serum
a normal or pathological serous fluid (as in a blister)

dt: {bc}what will be, will be {dx}compare {dxt|che sarà, sarà|che sara, sara:f|}{/dx}

{bc}{d_link|blood serum|blood serum} that is obtained from an individual who has recovered from an infectious disease and contains antibodies against the infectious agent of the disease and may be administered by intravenous transfusion to prevent or treat infection in other individuals

dt.t: In addition to its use during the 1918 flu pandemic, {wi}convalescent serum{/wi} therapy also was used for the measles, mumps and polio in the first half of the 20th century. It became less relevant with the advent of vaccines and antiviral drugs.

dt: The terms {it}convalescent serum{/it} and {i_link|convalescent plasma|convalescent plasma} are often used interchangeably.

shortdef: blood serum that is obtained from an individual who has recovered from an infectious disease and contains antibodies against the infectious agent of the disease and may be administered by intravenous transfusion to prevent or treat infection in other individuals
